data.title: Extensions will not install
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. ctrl+p
2. install any extension
3. button changes to "Installing" but nothing gets installed.

data.title: feature request: configure OpenType font features

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
From #6918: Please support configuration of [font features](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings), and possibly also support "user friendly" alternate configuration via [font variants](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-variant).

Font features allow the user to control the use of alternate glyphs and ligatures. For example:
- normal vs slashed zero
- lining vs old-style numbers
- small-caps
- fractions (and horizontal vs diagonal)
- ordinals

Issue #6918 demonstrates that fonts may include useful nonstandard feature tags, so it is important that the user is not restricted to just the "font variant" options.

Example:

``` json
"editor.fontFeatures": {"zero": 1, "salt": 3, "COOL": 1},
```

data.title: Where the mouse prompt have shortcut keys so much the better.
data.body: Where the mouse prompt have shortcut keys so much the better.THK.

data.title: Allow for menu contributions in folders of the explorer
Feature request: per-language settings
data.body:
Feature request: per-language settings (split from #6918).

I propose one of the two following feature be added to settings.json:
1. Allow certain editor settings to be configured per language. Example:

``` json
"editor.language-specific" : [
  { "language": "java", "tabSize": 4 },
  { "language": ["haskell","**/*.ks"],
    "tabCompletion": false,
    "tabSize": 2
  }
]
```

_or_
2. Support a general mechanism for language-specific configuration. Settings, provided by vscode or extensions, may specify whether they are allowed to be language specific in their schema. Let `workspace.getConfiguration` take an optional language-id argument (where the default behavior is to return the language-agnostic setting). Example:

``` json
"language-specific" : [
  { "language": "java",
    "editor.tabSize": 4,
    "myextension.foo": false
  },
  { "language": ["haskell","**/*.ks"],
    "editor.tabCompletion": false,
    "editor.tabSize": 2,
    "myextension.foo": true
  }
]
```

data.title: Prompts for loss of changes when closing split
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a document
2. Click on the Split Editor button
3. Make a change to the file
4. Go to close one of the two splits

You now get warned about data loss and whether or not to save the changes, even though you aren't closing the file completely. If you click on "Don't save", one of the splits closes, leaving you with the file still open, but your changes are lost! This happens regardless of which split you made the changes in and which split you close.

The desired behaviour would, surely, be just to close the split, leaving the file still open, no loss of changes and no prompt of loss of changes?

data.title: Extra spaces between braces when formatting JavaScript objects
data.body:
There seems to be no option to prevent inserting extra space after and before braces when formatting JS objects.
For example, when I expect
`var obj = { x: 5, y: 7 };`
to look like
`var obj = {x: 5, y: 7};`

data.title: IMHO suggest widget should not bind Home/End by default
data.body:
It makes the suggest widget mess with my typing.

Here I am not using the suggest widget explicitly, it is popping up by itself.
- I type `lines`
- then `End`
- then `;`
- the result is broken code

IMHO it is cool that I can go to the end of the suggestion list, but I think the usefulness of that is far smaller than the usefulness of going to the end of the line while typing (having not triggered suggestions manually). 

![rjw74swwmp](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/17580489/45d4f9dc-5f9f-11e6-86d0-ce78c417357b.gif)

data.title: Support shortcuts to paste content from Linux different  X server's selections

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Fedora 24 (Xfce4 desktop)

In Linux, X server has 3 selections for clipboard: primary, secondary, and clipboard ([wiki](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Clipboard)).

I think `Ctrl-V` is for clipboard. Some Linux apps offer `Shift-Insert` for primary selection. Would you please consider supporting this? My suggestions:
- `Ctrl-V`: clipboard
- `Shift-Insert`: primary
- `Ctrl-Shift-Insert`: secondary

Thank you,

![screen shot 2016-08-10 at 7 45 03 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/881944/17575926/6582d7a2-5f33-11e6-9370-b0c2af684c9a.png)

data.title: workbench.action.quickOpen opens file in existing tab instead of creating a new tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Make these your keyboard shortcuts and save:
   // Place your key bindings in this file to overwrite the defaults
   [
   { "key": "alt+shift+s",          "command": "workbench.action.gotoSymbol" },
   { "key": "alt+g",                   "command": "editor.action.goToDeclaration",
                                    "when": "editorTextFocus" },
   { "key": "alt+shift+f",             "command": "editor.action.referenceSearch.trigger",
                                    "when": "editorTextFocus" },
   { "key": "alt+o",                "command": "workbench.action.quickOpen" },
   { "key": "alt+shift+o",                "command": "workbench.action.quickOpen" },
   { "key": "f7",          "command": "workbench.action.tasks.build" },
   { "key": "ctrl+k ctrl+d", "command": "editor.action.format" }
   ]
2. Open a project folder.
3. Navigate to a file.
4.  Press keyboard shortcut "alt+shift+o" to trigger workbench.action.quickOpen
5. Type in a file name.

Result:
File opens in the existing tab.

Expected:
File opens in a new tab.

data.title: Allow to disable developer related keybindings in extension host

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Win8.1

The extension development host maps `ctrl+shift+i` to Chrome developer tools and does not allow this to be overridden by keyboard shortcut settings. Are there any other keyboard shortcuts that the development host overrides? Is it possible to remove this behavior so that the development host behaves closer to normal-mode vscode?

data.title: Go back should remember line / column
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.5.0-insider (666ed83a2d465257201cdac215a553ddee3cccbe, 2016-08-10T09:04:04.509Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go to some line/column (eg. `10:30`)
2. Press `Cmd + Up`
3. Press `Cmd + Shift + Enter` to enter new line above (eg. to put new import)
4. Press `Ctrl + -` to go back to location you were editing

Cursor will jump to line number `10` and most likely column `1` (if this happens to be empty line)

Ideally if it would jump to line `11:30` so you can continue typing whatever you were typing

Sublime handles it pretty good (will go to exact location that cursor was - code wise - not line number wise)

Use case is similar to: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10409

data.title: and, or, ... keywords not highlighted
data.body:
For readability it would great, if the keywords `and`, `or`, etc. are highlighted in languages where they are available like Python and C++. See GitHub's highlighting as an example:

Python:

``` python
if a or b and c:
    pass
```

C++:

``` cpp
if (a or b and c || d && e) {
}
```

(notice how ||, && aren't red here)

data.title: Git commit using '--signoff'
data.body:
This PR addresses issue #7010. It adds support for committing with the `--signoff` flag enabled.

Instead of using a checkbox under the commit message input as suggested by @FrenchBen in the original issue, I added 2 actions to the context menu since signed off commits are fairly rare.

![vscode-git-signoff-actions](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2205595/17571961/bb9812fa-5f52-11e6-96a6-7d9810a618aa.jpg)

data.title: Register Cmd+Up as cursor position change in editor history
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.5.0-insider (666ed83a2d465257201cdac215a553ddee3cccbe, 2016-08-10T09:04:04.509Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open file
2. Go to line 10
3. Go to line 20
4. Go to line 30
5. Press Cmd + Up
6. Press Ctrl + -
7. Press Cmd + Up
8. Press Ctrl + -

It should jump to line 30, but it jumps to line 20

if you repeat `Cmd + Up and Ctrl + -` it will go to line 10

Compared it with Sublime and they are doing it right (it goes to line 30)

Use case is this: 
Im working on given line and use something that is not imported - so I click Cmd+Up to add new import and then I want to go back - but often time it will go to some previous location making it dissorienting

data.title: Failed to save 'thefilename': A system error occured (ENOTSUP: operation not supported on socket, fdatasync)
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  VSCode Insiders - since August 9th build
- OS Version:
  OS X 10.11.4, working with files in a VMware Fusion 8.1.1 hosted Windows 7 (6.1.7601) mounted volume

I know this is a strange setup, but it has worked nearly flawless for me for quite some time, and still works in the most recent standard VSCode edition as well as other editors such as Sublime Text 2 & 3.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Using VMware Fusion, create a Windows 7 VM
2. Share a folder in Windows 7 containing text files
3. In OS X, mount the Windows shared folder as a volume (i.e. `cd /Volumes && mkdir /Volumes/winsrc && mount_smbfs //username@windowshostname/sharedfolder /Volumes/winsrc`)
4. Open the VSCode Insiders build from August 9th (or 10th) and open a file from the newly mounted volume.
5. Make a change to the file and save.
6. You should see the error: "Failed to save 'thefilename': A system error occured (ENOTSUP: operation not supported on socket, fdatasync)" -- (side note: "occured" is misspelled in the error text)

From what little related information I've been able to find, I suspect it might be an upstream issue with Electron and/or NodeJS, but I've been unable to track down the issue/forum post that led me to believe that was the case yesterday.

If there's anything else I can provide, please let me know.

Thank you all for all your incredibly hard work.  In a very short amount of time, VSCode has become my immediate go-to for all things text edit related and has been a pleasure to use since its first public release.

-Russ

data.title: Chinese (and other languages) IME does not work correctly in Edge and IE11
data.body:
Using the Chinese (and other languages) IME (Input Method Editors) with Monaco in Windows 10 does not work correctly with Monaco in Edge and IE11 browsers.  It seems to work fine in Chrome.

Setup to use Chinese IME, as shown below in Windows 10 task bar:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5246869/17568837/860ab276-5f13-11e6-9ca0-3502b6c71f5d.png)

Typing hazni<space> should give 哈祝你 as it does here.  I have no idea what this spells.  Hopefully, nothing offensive.

Now try to do that in Monaco at https://microsoft.github.io/monaco-editor/playground.html 
Using Chrome - works pretty well
Using IE - flaky, but sometimes works
Using Edge - doesn't really work at all
